title: Torque and work - ratio of change in KE for disks

content.question: A net force <math alttext="F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is exerted tangentially to the outside of a uniform disk of rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> over an angular displacement of <math alttext="delta theta sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, causing the disk to gain rotational kinetic energy <math alttext="delta K sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. The same net force is then exerted tangentially to the outside of a second uniform disk over the same angular displacement, causing the second disk to gain rotational kinetic energy <math alttext="delta K sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. The second disk has the same radius as the first disk, but with rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub 2 equals, 2 I sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. Which of the following is equal to the ratio <math alttext="The ratio delta K sub 1 to, delta K sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>:</mo><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> ?

choices.label: The ratio cannot be determined without knowing the relative masses of the disks.

unit.text: 6: Energy and Momentum of Rotating Systems
